events.title: First Women's Rights Convention Begins in Seneca Falls
events.description: The Seneca Falls Convention, the first women's rights convention in the United States, began on July 19, 1848, marking a pivotal moment in the women's suffrage movement.
events.significance: It initiated organized advocacy for women's rights, including the right to vote, influencing future feminist movements.

events.title: German Forces Launch Attack on Leningrad
events.description: On July 19, 1941, during World War II, German troops began their assault on Leningrad, leading to the prolonged Siege of Leningrad by Nazi forces.
events.significance: This siege became one of the longest and deadliest in history, symbolizing Soviet resilience during the war.

events.title: Viking 1 Sends First Images from Mars
events.description: NASA's Viking 1 sent the first clear images of the Martian surface back to Earth on July 19, 1976, marking the beginning of detailed exploration of Mars.
events.significance: These images expanded knowledge of Mars and paved the way for future planetary exploration missions.

events.title: Mount St. Helens Volcanic Eruption
events.description: On July 19, 1980, increased seismic activity signaled the impending eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington State, which would occur days later.
events.significance: This event alerted scientists and authorities to volcanic hazards and greatly contributed to volcanology research.
